title: Financial Manual
subtitle: Understanding Your Financial Data and Making Better Business Decisions

revenue.title: Revenue Analysis
revenue.description: Learn how to analyze your income streams and growth patterns

content.title: What is Revenue?
content.description: Revenue is the total amount of money your business earns from sales before any deductions.
content.example: If you sold $50,000 worth of products this month, that's your revenue.

content.title: Revenue Growth
content.description: Track how your revenue changes over time to understand business performance.
content.example: A 10% month-over-month growth means your business is expanding.

content.title: Revenue Streams
content.description: Different sources of income help diversify your business risk.
content.example: Product sales, service fees, subscription revenue, licensing.

decisions.action: Investigate causes: market changes, competition, product issues
Consider scaling operations, hiring, or expanding to new markets

costs.title: Cost Management
costs.description: Understanding and controlling your business expenses

content.title: Fixed vs Variable Costs
content.description: Fixed costs stay the same regardless of sales volume, variable costs change with production.
content.example: Rent (fixed) vs raw materials (variable)

content.title: Cost Structure
content.description: The proportion of different cost types affects your business flexibility.
content.example: High fixed costs require consistent sales to break even.

content.title: Cost per Unit
content.description: How much it costs to produce or deliver one unit of your product/service.
content.example: If total costs are $30,000 and you sold 1,000 units, cost per unit is $30.

decisions.action: Identify cost reduction opportunities or consider price increases

decisions.scenario: Cost per unit is too high
decisions.action: Look for efficiency improvements, bulk purchasing, or automation

profitability.title: Profitability Metrics
profitability.description: Key indicators of business financial health

content.title: Gross Profit
content.description: Revenue minus direct costs of producing your product or service.
content.example: $50,000 revenue - $20,000 cost of goods = $30,000 gross profit

content.title: Net Profit
content.description: What remains after all expenses, taxes, and costs are deducted.
content.example: $30,000 gross profit - $15,000 operating expenses = $15,000 net profit

content.title: Profit Margins
content.description: Percentage of revenue that becomes profit, indicates efficiency.
content.example: 30% gross margin means you keep $0.30 of every dollar in revenue.

decisions.action: Reduce costs, increase prices, or improve operational efficiency
Urgent cost reduction or revenue improvement needed

cashflow.title: Cash Flow Management
cashflow.subtitle: Understanding your money movement and liquidity

basics.title: Cash Flow Basics
basics.description: Understanding how money moves in and out of your business

content.title: What is Cash Flow?
content.description: The movement of money into and out of your business over a specific period.
content.example: You might be profitable on paper but lack cash to pay bills.

content.title: Operating Cash Flow
content.description: Cash generated from core business operations.
content.example: Customer payments minus supplier payments and salaries.

content.title: Free Cash Flow
content.description: Cash available after necessary capital expenditures.
content.example: Operating cash flow minus equipment purchases and facility improvements.

decisions.action: Speed up collections, delay non-essential payments, secure financing
Consider investments, debt reduction, or growth initiatives

runway.title: Cash Runway Analysis
runway.description: How long your business can operate with current cash levels

content.title: Burn Rate
content.description: How much cash your business uses each month.
content.example: If you spend $10,000 monthly and earn $8,000, burn rate is $2,000.

content.title: Runway Calculation
content.description: Current cash divided by monthly burn rate.
content.example: $50,000 cash รท $2,000 burn rate = 25 months runway

content.title: Break-even Point
content.description: When your monthly income equals monthly expenses.
content.example: Need to increase revenue by $2,000 or reduce costs by $2,000.

decisions.action: Immediate action needed: reduce costs, increase sales, or raise funds
Consider strategic investments in growth or market expansion

forecasting.title: Cash Flow Forecasting
forecasting.description: Predicting future cash needs and planning accordingly

content.title: Revenue Projections
content.description: Estimating future income based on trends and pipeline.
content.example: If growing 5% monthly, expect $52,500 next month from $50,000 this month.

content.title: Seasonal Patterns
content.description: Many businesses have predictable cash flow cycles.
content.example: Retail businesses often see higher cash flow during holiday seasons.

content.title: Scenario Planning
content.description: Preparing for best case, worst case, and most likely scenarios.
content.example: Plan for 20% revenue drop to ensure business continuity.

decisions.action: Arrange credit line, accelerate collections, or delay payments
Plan strategic investments, debt reduction, or expansion

aichat.title: AI Financial Assistant
aichat.subtitle: Maximizing insights from your AI-powered financial advisor

effective-questions.title: Asking Effective Questions
effective-questions.description: How to get the most valuable insights from AI analysis

content.title: Be Specific
content.description: Ask targeted questions about specific metrics or time periods.
content.example: Instead of 'How's my business?', ask 'Why did my gross margin decline in Q2?'

content.title: Provide Context
content.description: Share relevant business context to get more accurate insights.
content.example: 'We launched a new product line in March' helps AI understand revenue changes.

content.title: Ask Follow-up Questions
content.description: Dig deeper into AI recommendations for actionable insights.
content.example: 'What specific steps should I take to improve cash flow?'

interpreting-insights.title: Understanding AI Recommendations
interpreting-insights.description: How to evaluate and act on AI-generated insights

content.title: Confidence Levels
content.description: AI provides confidence indicators for its analysis and predictions.
content.example: High confidence recommendations are safer to act on immediately.

content.title: Data Dependencies
content.description: AI insights are only as good as the data you provide.
content.example: Incomplete data may lead to inaccurate recommendations.

content.title: Business Logic Check
content.description: Always validate AI suggestions against your business knowledge.
content.example: AI might not know about seasonal factors specific to your industry.

decision-validation.title: Validating Decisions
decision-validation.description: Using AI to test your business decisions before implementation

content.title: Scenario Testing
content.description: Ask AI to model the impact of potential decisions.
content.example: 'What happens to cash flow if I hire 3 new employees?'

content.title: Risk Assessment
content.description: Get AI analysis of potential risks and mitigation strategies.
content.example: 'What are the risks of expanding to a new market?'

content.title: Alternative Options
content.description: Explore different approaches to achieve your goals.
content.example: 'What are 3 ways to increase revenue by 20%?'

best-practices: Start with overview questions, then drill down into specifics
Cross-reference AI insights with your own business knowledge
Use AI for data analysis, but make decisions based on complete context
Ask for multiple scenarios when planning major changes
Regularly validate AI recommendations against actual results
sample-questions: What trends do you see in my revenue over the past 6 months?
Which expense categories are growing fastest?
How does my cash flow compare to industry benchmarks?
What would happen if I increased my prices by 10%?
When should I consider hiring additional staff?
What are the early warning signs I should watch for?

terms.definition: Money owed to your business by customers for goods or services delivered.
terms.example: Outstanding invoices that haven't been paid yet.

terms.definition: Money your business owes to suppliers or vendors.
terms.example: Bills you've received but haven't paid yet.

terms.definition: The difference between current assets and current liabilities.
terms.example: Cash and inventory minus bills due within a year.

terms.definition: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization.
terms.example: A measure of operating performance excluding financing and accounting decisions.

terms.definition: The rate at which a company spends its available cash.
terms.example: If you have $100,000 and spend $10,000/month, burn rate is $10,000/month.
